title: On the Mysteries of MAX NAE-SAT

sections.an optimal algorithm for max nae-{3}3\\{: In SectionÂ 4, we tackle the problem of finding an optimal approximation algorithm for MAX NAE-{3}3\{3\}-SAT. Our approach follows a similar template to that of  for MAX CUT. LikeÂ , we consider the max-min problem of finding an RPR2 rounding function fğ‘“f which achieves at least the optimal approximation ratio for any distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} of triples of unit vectors (pairs of unit vectors for MAX CUT). Once we fix a distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, the performance of fğ‘“f can be expressed using a double integral. Using calculus of variations, we can then produce an integral equation that must be satisfied by the optimal fğ‘“f, known as a Fredholm integral equation of the second kind (c.f., [ref]27). If we discretize fğ‘“f as a step function, the integral equation becomes a system of linear equations (c.f., SectionÂ 6 of the full version ofÂ ). Thus, like inÂ , we can efficiently compute an arbitrarily close approximation of the optimal function for MAX NAE-{3}3\{3\}-SAT. We found that the optimal approximation ratio is approximately 0.90890.90890.9089.
